accussed_details.name: Muhammad Hussain
allegation: Violation of Section 18(a) read with Section 27 of the Drugs Act, 1940

complaint_summary: Muhammad Hussain was accused of stocking sub-standard drugs at his medical store, violating Section 18(a) read with Section 27 of the Drugs Act, 1940. Samples taken by the Inspector of Drugs revealed foreign particles and suspended material in the drugs.
investigation_summary: On 29-09-1975, Inspector Munawar Iqbal inspected Hussain Medical Store and collected samples of Chloroquine Injection, Batch No. 59. The samples were analyzed by the Drugs Testing Laboratory, Lahore, which confirmed non-compliance with B.P. standards. Notice was issued to the appellant, but he failed to provide warranty or purchase invoice.
judgment_summary: The appellate court ruled that the Drug Court constituted under the Drugs Act, 1976 lacked jurisdiction to try offences under the repealed Drugs Act, 1940. The conviction and sentence of Muhammad Hussain were declared illegal and set aside.
punishment: Conviction set aside; bail bond discharged.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal allowed; conviction and sentence overturned.
legal_arguments: Drug Court under Drugs Act, 1976 lacked jurisdiction to try offences under Drugs Act, 1940.
Section 6(e) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 allows prosecution for offences under repealed laws unless explicitly barred.
Procedural changes affecting vested rights are not retrospective unless expressly stated.
witnesses: Muhammad Aslam (Employee of Ch. Medical Store)

witness_statement.Khadim Hussain: Prescribed Chloroquine Injection for malaria patients.
witness_statement.Shamshad Ahmad: Testified that appellant refused to sell prescribed medicine.
witness_statement.Muhammad Aslam: Denied handwriting and signature on warranty document.

key_issues: Jurisdiction of Drug Court under Drugs Act, 1976

maxims.Retrospective Procedural Law: Procedural laws are retrospective unless affecting vested rights.

legal_terms.Mens Rea: Mental state indicating intention or knowledge of wrongdoing.

words_and_phrases.Sub-standard Drugs: Drugs failing to meet prescribed quality standards.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around jurisdictional issues arising from the repeal of the Drugs Act, 1940 and its replacement by the Drugs Act, 1976. The appellate court ruled that procedural changes affecting vested rights are not retrospective unless explicitly stated. The conviction was overturned due to lack of jurisdiction by the Drug Court under the new law.
